title: Functional Interactions Between Memory and Recognition Judgments.
abstract: One issue facing agents that accumulate large bodies of knowledge is determining whether they have knowledge that is relevant to its current goals. Performing comprehensive searches of long-term memory in every situation can be computationally expensive and disruptive to task reasoning. In this paper, we demonstrate that the recognition judgment-a heuristic for whether memory structures have been previously perceived - can serve as a low-cost indicator of the existence of potentially relevant knowledge.We present an approach for computing both context-dependent and context-independent recognition judgments using processes and data shared with declarative memories. We then describe an initial, efficient implementation in the Soar cognitive architecture and evaluate our system in a word sense disambiguation task, showing that it reduces the number of memory searches without degrading agent performance.
